Award.AwardTitle: Post-Conflict Recovery, Disaster Mitigation, and Extractive Energy Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Americans, like people around the world, increasingly seek innovative solutions to meet the growing demand for energy, while also minimizing anthropogenic climate impacts and reducing political conflicts at home and abroad. At the same time, the extraction of energy resources such as natural gas can paradoxically promote violence and lead to environmental disasters that halt the economic development they were designed to achieve. This project uses cultural anthropology fieldwork to explore the linkages between official efforts to control violence and nature, how energy projects and power relate to peace. The data and findings from this research will aid governments and businesses pursuing energy development projects, and the civil society organizations and academics working with them, to better understand their meanings and effects. This knowledge and awareness may help lead to more effective policies and projects that stop cycles of political violence, dehumanization, and inequality.

Kristin Doughty of the University of Rochester will examine how the cultural politics of energy, risk of natural disaster, and reconciliation are intertwined within post-conflict contexts. Rwanda's Lake Kivu provides a uniquely productive site for this study because of its distinct chemical composition and its location in a place recovering from genocide. Over the past decade, while rebuilding the country in the wake of the 1994 genocide, the Rwandan government has developed contracts to build industrial-scale gas-fueled power projects to extract methane from Lake Kivu. The methane extraction project has two stated aims: first, to reduce dangerous levels of unstable gasses dissolved in the lake and thus prevent it from an unpredictable, and deadly, explosion; and second, to provide much-needed power to fuel development for the region and country. The PI, who has conducted research in Rwanda since 2002, will conduct to study how people living alongside the lake experience the transformations brought about by the gas extraction project. Working closely with the Rwandan Lake Kivu Monitoring Program, the PI will collect data through participant observation, interviews, life histories, and document analysis. This research project aims to improve scientific understandings of this innovative methane extraction project. This project can help improve the effectiveness of this and other energy extraction projects and reduce their unintended negative impacts by providing long-term, empirically rich, qualitative, historicized research that captures the diverse perspectives of the people affected.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined how the cultural politics of energy, risk of natural disaster, and reconciliation are intertwined within post-conflict contexts. Rwanda's Lake Kivu provides a uniquely productive site for this study because of its distinct chemical composition and its location in a place recovering from genocide. Over the past decade, while rebuilding the country in the wake of the 1994 genocide, the Rwandan government developed contracts with several international companies to build industrial-scale gas-fueled power projects to extract methane from Lake Kivu. The methane extraction project had two stated aims: first, to reduce dangerous levels of unstable gasses dissolved in the lake and thus prevent it from an unpredictable, and deadly, explosion; and second, to provide much-needed power to fuel development for the region and country. The PI conducted ten months of ethnographic research in Rwanda over four years to understand how people experience the transformations brought by the new energy projects. The PI collected data through participant observation, interviews, life histories, and document analysis, working closely with Rwandan collaborators including the Rwandan Lake Kivu Monitoring Program, which was established by the Rwandan government to oversee extraction.

The research design gathered perspectives from people across diverse levels of society who were involved in and impacted by the methane extraction project to create a three-dimensional perspective on extraction. The PI focused on Rubavu and Karongi, lakeside towns where extraction operations were centered, with four key groups: 1) Rwandans whose lives are entangled with the lake, including fishermen, fish sellers, boat operators, school teachers, community health workers, local mediators, women's council members, hotel workers, market women. 2) American and Rwandan methane extractors and engineers and their European funders, including visits to corporate offices, the barges, and power plants. 3) Rwandan scientists involved in monitoring the lake through the Lake Kivu Monitoring Program, and their international collaborators from Europe and the US, including participation in international scientific conferences about the lake, student trainings on the lake, and work in the lakeside laboratories. 4) Rwandan government officials, including in the Rwandan Energy Group and National Center for Electricity Control, and visits to hydropower plants, peat plants, and solar plants around the country.

While this lake and the gas extraction efforts have long garnered international scientific attention focused on the lake's ecology, physical, or chemical properties, this research is the first social science study of methane extraction on Lake Kivu. This research findings provide a historical record of changing local and scientific perspectives on the only industrial scale dissolved methane-to-power project in the world in a country seen by many as a model for the rest of the African continent. Generalizable findings show how vulnerable people build lives and imagine justice under unpredictable environmental and political conditions and within shifting energy landscapes. This project contributes to existing anthropological work on extraction in two specific ways that help to retheorize social repair in new energy landscapes and changing climates in the twenty-first century. First, unlike work that emphasizes the human and environmental risks of doing resource extraction, particularly around oil, findings from this project show how scientific, corporate, and governmental actors framed Kivu's methane as itself the risk, and with what effects. Second, unlike prevailing work that emphasizes violent conflict around energy infrastructures this project examines the absence of overt conflict around methane pipelines, powerlines, and power plants. The findings from this project can help improve the effectiveness of this and other energy extraction projects and reduce their unintended negative impacts by providing long-term, empirically rich, qualitative, historicized research that captures the diverse perspectives of the people impacted.
